article.title: Implications from GW170817 and I-Love-Q relations for relativistic hybrid stars

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the left panel of Figure 2 primarily illustrate?
choices: The relationship between the mass and tidal deformability of compact stars.
The relationship between the mass and radius of non-rotating hybrid stars.
The impact of different EOSs on the maximum mass of a neutron star.
The evolution of mass and radius as a compact star transitions to a black hole.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key difference is highlighted in the right panel of Figure 2 when comparing hybrid hadron-quark stars to realistic neutron stars?
choices: The maximum mass limit for hybrid stars is significantly lower than for neutron stars.
The relationship between mass and tidal deformability for hybrid stars cannot be accurately approximated as linear.
Realistic neutron stars do not exhibit a stable third family branch, unlike hybrid stars.
The tidal deformability of hybrid stars is consistently higher than that of neutron stars for a given mass.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the dashed-dotted curves lying within the 90% credible upper bound in the left panel of Figure 3?
choices: They demonstrate that all tested EOS models are fully compatible with the GW170817 data.
They highlight the possibility of a hybrid star-neutron star binary system as a plausible source of GW170817.
They indicate that the chirp mass of GW170817 can only be explained by the presence of a third family compact object.
They demonstrate the inconsistency of purely hadronic EOS models with the observed tidal deformability constraints.

multiple_choice_question.text: What important conclusion can be drawn from the I-Love-Q relations presented in Figure 4?
choices: The I-Love-Q relations cease to be universal when considering hybrid stars in the third family.
The presence of a sharp first-order phase transition at the hadron-quark interface significantly alters the I-Q relation.
Despite the sharp phase transition, the I-Love-Q relations remain largely universal even for hybrid stars in the third family.
Rapidly rotating hybrid stars exhibit significant deviations from the I-Love-Q relations compared to slowly rotating ones.
